elements.text: [Part One]
Robotic stomping stops.
Progress.
233 new files located.
Link up. Let’s see them. Ow!
Your dataport fully functional.
I thought so.
The manufacturer of this hardware recommends that you lay your hand palm upwards when connecting.
Yes, I do know. Now shut up and get on with it.
Beeping.
Hi, this is Federer. Who’s there?
[OC]: (a woman) It’s Lake. How are you getting on?
Really badly. There’s nothing in this quarter.
[OC]: Nothing?
Nothing useful. Books, chat room archive, pictures of dogs dressed in bee costumes, bad poetry. Nothing secure. I’m just downloading it... ow!
Exchange complete.
Delete and keep looking. Ow, that stings.
[OC]: You all right?
The Scandroid stomps off.
I’m getting a stinging sensation in the skin around my dataport every time a Scandroid links into it.
[OC]: You shouldn’t have installed it on the inside of your wrist. It’s too close to the nerves. I had mine moved to just below my elbow, and never had any trouble since.
Well, I’m coming back in a couple of minutes. Book me in with a cybertech and I'll see about doing that.
[OC]: Give it another half hour, Fed. Marriott really seems to think there’s something in your sector.
Oh, I’ve been out here all day. What does he think I...
This is priority information.
Oh. Oh, it looks like we’ve got something. I’ll call you back.
Prepare to receive priority information.
Yeah, gimme... hey! Ow! No, stop it. Hey. (and other cries of discomfort, until thud.)
(unintelligible under Federer’s cries until-) Information has not been delivered. Priority information. Priority information.
Munm,, that portmanteau case we found had an ID backup chip sewn in the lining.
Oh yeah? Give it here. Gabe, this is a fake.
I know, but it looks a pretty good fake. We might be able to sell it on.
I’m not risking selling a fake to a good contact.
Don’t sell it to one of the usual contacts. Sell it anonymous, cheap. Better than wasting it.
You know that’s not how I like to work, Gabe.
We need to see something, Mum. Maybe we should shift to another sector before this one gets mined out.
The Clinic won’t be here forever. We'll ride it out, and we won’t compromise our principles just because of them.
You’ve got principles?
Don’t be funny. Just because we don’t always stick to them doesn’t mean they’re not worth having.
You just like thinking you’re better than them.
Of course I do, because I am, and so are you.
Shh.
Faint sound of the Tardis materialising.
What's that?
Door opens.
Is it coming from that thing?
Yeah. I... There’s somebody in it.
(distant) Hello! I’m the Doctor. I wonder if... oh, oh, oh. Ow! (and other cries of pain.)
Is he... dead?
I don’t think so. Let’s get down there, see if he’s got anything.
Here, he said he was a doctor. Maybe he’s with the Clinic?
Yeah. You bring him up. I'll hail the Clinic and see if we can get any cash out of them.
You’re gonna hold him to ransom?
Course I am. That’s your problem, Gabe. No eye for an angle. Your father was the same. Now get down there and bring him up. And try and keep him in one piece.
Fed? Are you there?
How long since you were last in contact, Lake?
Twenty minutes, maybe? He couldn’t have got out of range.
No, of course not. Just watch. He’ll come back insisting his comm went dead. In the meantime, he’s slacking.
I don’t think so, Doctor Marriott. The last time we spoke, his Scandroid had just found something. What if pirates have ‘napped him? Look, I really think
I don’t care what you think, Lake. I can read a personality, and I knew they’d dumped a slacker on me the second I saw that boy. This doesn’t look good.
Doesn't look good to who, exactly?
Tevez is arriving this afternoon.
They’re sending a company accountant? Why didn’t I hear about this?
You probably weren't listening, Bridge. And she’s the company accountant these days.
What happened to Nardini?
Disappeared, along with about 6 million Q. Tevez is in charge now, and I don’t want anyone looking like they’re wasting this project’s time and money.
New voice message, Doctor Marriott.
[OC]: We're holding one of your people. If you want him back, I’ve attached a map showing where to meet us. There’s a price, but I reckon you can afford it.
Told you.
Tevez won't be impressed if we’re throwing away money on a replaceable resource like Federer. Where's the rendezvous?
A derelict shack about two clicks north-east.
I’m assigning this one to you, Bridge. You’ve got a ransom budget of 5000.
They’ll want more than that.
Well, I’m not giving you more than that. If he can’t look after himself out there, that’s his problem. If they won’t deal, then just come back. He isn’t worth it.
Okay.
Oh, but try to find out what happened to his Scandroid. If there was anything on there, I want to see it. And try to get back here before Tevez
She’s coming in to land now, Doctor Marriott.
(sigh) Signal to her that I'll be there asap. Just try to leave without her seeing you.
The Doctor wakes up.
Have you scanned him yet, Gabe?
The imprinter won't read him. I’m just getting a blank.
Let me try.
See?
Weird.
Excuse me, madam. What are you doing?
Be quiet and stay still.
I’ve twisted my ankle. I’m just checking it’s not broken. Oof! Oh, ticklish, in an unpleasant way. That’s a device for taking an imprint of the human brain, I assume.
Be quiet.
Well, if you insist, but I can save you time by telling you it won’t work on me.
Got an application in your skull to block it, have you?
Hey, we could use that.
Tell us how it works and how to get it out, and we might let you live.
Well, I think we can do without the threats. No, it’s not an application or a trick. My brain’s just... different.
Really. My son here’s got a cross-wired brain too.
Don’t tell people that.
What do you mean, cross-wired?
He’s analogic. His brain can’t process digital.
Digital? What, you mean direct digital input into the brain? Organic digital transfer?
What else? Even the boy isn’t as hard of thinking as you.
Mum.
Hmm. Even humanity didn’t develop a form of pure digital information that the brain could absorb until... well, this must be the 32” century.
I’m not sure he is with the Clinic.
You never know, they might need the odd moron for experiments and so on.
Madam, I am not a moron. Now who are you people?
I’m Gabe Stillinger.
And this is your mother.
Denise.
So what do we do with him?
The Clinic signalled they were coming to meet us, so they must have someone missing.
I found some gadgets in his pockets.
Oh, give those back.
Oh, nice.
You have no hope of understanding how to operate them.
We don’t need to understand them to sell them, any more than we need to understand you to sell you.
What?
Tie him up. We should set off for the rendezvous
Oh.
Mz Tevez. I hope you haven’t been waiting long.
Nine minutes.
Is that long, in your opinion?
I put it to good use. Can we walk and talk?
Certainly. I understand you’ve never been to the Valley before.
Never had reason to. I haven’t had the time to research it either, so fill me in. How much material is there in the Valley?
This is only an estimate, but the Valley is twelve clicks from one extreme to the other, and it’s reckoned there are maybe four billion data storage devices here.
Four billion?
With another sixty thousand items being dumped daily.
What sort of material?

It ranges from the kind of chip you’d find in a refrigerator or a pet collar through to corporate hub systems. About eighty percent of it’s broken or stripped, but that still leaves a massive amount of recoverable data.
What's the legal status?

It’s a policing nightmare, so it’s ideal, really. It was supposed to be part of a recycling programme that fell through decades ago. The authorities tried to keep quiet about it. You saw the floating homes on your way in?
Yes?
Data pirates. They hold private sector recycling licences, and most of them trade the odd bit of junk for appearances’ sake, but it’s all about the data really.
That’s got to make working here a little dangerous.
Oh, a little, yes.
Hello? It’s Claudia Bridge from the Clinic? You said you’d found one of our people.
Shall we talk money?
Where is he?
In the next room.
Let me see him first. How do I know he’s really here?
Gabe, bring him out.
[OC]: Is she armed?
I am, yes.
[OC]: Have you got her covered, Mum?
Of course.
Oof! (thud) Ah, hello.
I’m sorry, what is this?
Eight thousand if you want him back.
Who told you he was one of ours? Did he?
I’ve never claimed to be anything I’m not.
No, but
He’s not one of us. He must be with you.
He’s not.
You might be bluffing, hoping we'll let him go anyway.
I’m not hoping anything. I’ve no idea who he is.
So why’d you come out here?
One of ours is missing, but this isn’t him.
Really. Then perhaps
Shut up. If you don’t start talking money then we'll kill him.
Ah.
Go ahead. It’s more than my job’s worth to pay you for him. Actually, what am I still doing here?
We’re not messing about. We will kill him.
(distant) Please, don’t waste our time again.
Last chance!
Energy weapon.
You appear to have missed.
Well, it would have been pointless if I’d killed you and she’d come running back wailing, ‘stop, stop don’t kill him, I'll pay up’.
It’s pointless anyway.
Worth a try. Anyway, we’ve got the stuff in his pockets.
Er, what about me?
What about you? (walks away)
Oh. Oh, well, I’ll see myself out, then, shall I?
[OC]: So who was he?
No idea. Just a wandering nutter. I’m going to have a scout around while I’m here, see if I can find Federer.
[OC]: I’ll let you know if he checks in.
Okay. So, they didn’t kill you.
Apparently not. I’m surprised you care enough to ask. Who are you?
Claudia Bridge.
Charmed to meet you. I’m the Doctor.
No hard feelings, but I wasn’t lying. I could never have cleared the funds to bring in a non-staff member.
You’d have stood by and let another person die because you couldn’t clear the funds?
What else could I have done?
Oh, helped me, perhaps? Did the moral centre of the universe shift whilst I was unconscious? Where am I, anyway? Looks like an enormous junk yard.
Obsoletion Valley, where old computers come to die.
So it is an enormous junk yard. How appallingly wasteful.
If you don’t know that, how did you get here?
Oh, I arrived in my ship. It’s just over... (effort) Oh, where’s it gone?
Stolen, probably. The pirates here will take anything.
Oh.
Sorry.
Oh, whoops. Er, the er hover-platform. Is that your transports?
Hover-platform? You talk like someone from the Republican Era. Yes, this is my glider.
Ah. Would you like some help looking for your friend?
Not friend, colleague. And how can you possibly help? Thirty seconds ago you didn’t even know where you were.
Answer me this. What’s happened to him?
I don’t know.
An unexplained disappearance, then.
I wouldn’t say
Explain it, then.
What's your point?
The unexplained is my speciality.
You just want to tag along to find this ship of yours.
Yes. But I want to help as well.
Well, all right. Just don’t annoy me.
Oh, I’m sure I can manage that.
Don’t be too confident. I’m very easily annoyed.
Stop! Stop! What have you got? Ah!
2: What are you doing?
I have priority information. These pirates were attempting to hijack it.
2: Do you need assistance?
No. But I must share data with you.
2: Contact. Share data. Priority information.
I am returning to the Clinic to deliver this information.
2: I will deliver the information to my operator.
(stomping away) Priority information.
This is a bracing way to travel.
It’s supposed to have a wind resistance filter, but it doesn’t seem to work.
Oh, I don’t mind.
You will after you swallow your first insect.
(laughs) They said you were here with a clinic. Are you a medic?
No, I’m a researcher and a Scandroid technician. We're out looking for materials.
What clinic gets materials from a place like this?
We specialise in personality surgery.
Personality sur... You mean artificially altering people’s personalities to order?
Mmm hmm. You must have heard of that, surely.
Oh, I’ve a very good grounding in the principles. But hold on. You get your materials from here? You’re using real people’s personal details?
Yes.
People leave that sort of thing lying around?

People are careless. Say they leave a backup brain print on their home system in case they have an accident, then say they buy a new system and don’t delete everything off the old one before chucking it. We find it and use it.
So you’re letting people impersonate other people? Letting your clients steal other people’s identities?
That’s not all we do. Alot of our business is purely aesthetic.
Aesthetic?
Most clients just want to change an aspect of themselves they’re dissatisfied with, but for the right price we will give somebody another person’s full personality.
That’s never been legal.
No? Sorry, it sounds as if you object.
I most certainly do. It’s immoral. It’s criminal.
We stay just the right side of legal. We also look for redundant material where the legal status isn’t an issue. It provides inspiration for a lot of the aesthetic work.
Ha.
No, really. A lot of people come to us looking for a more... retro aspect to their personality. People who rail against it just don’t understand it.
I understand it only too well. Probably better than you do. Oh, I’d forgotten what a decadent age this is.
Then you must have a terrible memory. Everybody who can afford it has work done.
Have you?
Only a little. I got it when I started at the Clinic.
And you regret it?
If I did, I'd ask for my money back. It’s designed to stop me regretting things. Keeps my conscience in check.
Oh, look down there. That’s my ship.
The blue thing?
Yes, the blue thing.
I'll take us down.
Did you want lactose and saccharin, Mz Tevez?
Just black, thank you. You’ve clearly been working hard out here, Marriott.
Thank you.
But it’s not enough to balance the cost. The risk factor has pushed up the budget twenty two percent. There are more efficient ways of achieving comparable results.
But we’re within profit margins.
Barely. And it doesn’t address the fact we could make bigger profits by more conventional means.
You haven’t taken into account what this project could produce in the future.
I don’t see anything that justifies the expenditure.
That’s because I haven't told you the real reason for coming here.
And that is?
I don’t suppose you’d take it on trust that it’s a good reason?

He said it was a good idea and I believed him. It won’t play well on my report. You’re a talented surgeon, Marriott. People are asking why you’re spending so much here, and so little operating back at your branch.
All right, then. I'll tell you.
Glider lands.
Is this really a vehicle?
Yes.
Looks like these guys here were trying to cart it away.
Yes. No pulse. He’s dead. Been pretty badly beaten as well.
Urgh, looks like the other one’s dead too. Probably got attacked by raiders.
So why didn’t they take anything? The Tardis is still here and look, their bags are loaded. There’s plenty to steal.
Well, since we’ve found your ship, you can get on your way, can’t you?
Hmm? No, not yet. I promised to help you find your colleague.
You really don’t have to. What is that?
A telescope.
Looks like an antique. Careful you don’t let it out of your
Ah ha.
What?
I think I see something. About half a kilometre away. Come on.
Hang on. Let’s take the glider.
Nonsense, Claudia. No harm in a little exercise. Come on, don’t shilly-shally. Keep up.
Zachary Kindell?
I know what you’re going to say.
That he was a volatile, immoral egotist?
Actually, I didn’t think you’d phrase it exactly like that.
But I’m not wrong, am I?
No, but I think we could still learn a lot by finding his research. Maybe now the world would be ready, rather than trying to hammer the genie back into the bottle.
There’s no evidence of any significant advances he made that we don’t already know about.
A man like that doesn’t just stop having ideas.
He might, if he tinkered with his brain one too many times.
He’d have made backup copies of his mind, though, surely. I mean, we could even bring him back.
You think he’s here?
It’s possible, but I don’t think so. But I do think some of his projects are. It isn’t guesswork. I’ve been trying to trace this material for years. Let me show you.
Doctor, slow down.
Hmm? Barely going at a canter. You must be out of shape. Ah. Is this him, Claudia?
Yep, that’s Fed.
I’m afraid he’s dead. Oh, I’m sorry, I didn’t intend that to rhyme. It’s hardly an appropriate time. Oh, good grief, I’ve done it again.
What’s happened to him?
I don’t know.
I thought you said you were a doctor.
There’s not a mark on him. No evidence of heart failure.
Let’s just get him back to the glider. One of the medics at the ship will know. That’s odd.
I know. I really can’t
I mean it’s odd that his Scandroid isn’t here.
Scandroid?
We use them to dig through all the tech and scan the storage units for material. But if its operator dies, it’s meant to signal the ship and wait with the body.
Well, it hasn't. Is there any circumstance under which it wouldn’t do that? And if there was, what would it do instead?
Junk, junk, out of date.
A Scandroid stomps up.
Hello, what are you up to?
Criminal grade, data pirate. You are not authorised for interaction. Do not impede me.
Ah, wait a second.
If you continue to impede me, I will be forced to use violence.
Well, then I'll be forced to use this.
Energy weapon.
That dis-disabling device is illegal. The Lonway Clinic will be displeased by your actions.
Oh, you’re the Clinic, are you? Well, let’s see what you’ve got.
You are not authorised... to access my data.
Will be in a second. Just tweaking your protocols, mate. Hang on a bit. Now, how’d you feel about handing that stuff over?
Prepare to receive priority information.
That sounds good. Let’s see it, then. Ah! Oh! Ow! Disengage! Disen... argh. (thud)
Information has not been delivered. (receding)Priority information.
Hmm. It’s more interesting than I expected.
So you'll recommend it?
I didn’t say that. Even if you find this material, we have no idea of its value. Any breakthroughs Kindell made will be decades old. They've probably been surpassed.
I don’t believe that.
Well, this isn’t a debating society. But you can rest assured I’m looking on this enterprise more charitably.
Intercom beeps.
Yes, Marriott.
[OC]: We’ve just spotted Federer’s Scandroid outside on its way back. No sign of him, though.
Download whatever it’s got. I’ll be down in a second.
[OC]: I’ll tell Sampson to get onto it.
What's this?
What? Oh, nothing important. One of our people’s late reporting in. I'll be back shortly. Feel free to
I'll come with you.
Oh. Yes. Well, feel free.
Thank you. I do. Lead on.
Glider lands.
Another body.
Data pirate. The same as Federer?
Yes. No sign of what’s happened to him. Just dead.
He’s definitely just seen a Scandroid.
Why? Does he have a ‘just seen a Scandroid’ expression on his face?
No, that’s what this device is for. Disabling Scandroids. And it’s been discharged recently.
Oh, let me take a look at it. An. So, where’s the Scandroid if he disabled it?
Oh, the effect doesn’t last long. It’s very crude.
Do you have any of these?
No, we don’t. They’re illegal.
I fail to see how those two facts are connected.
It’s not worth drawing attention to yourself with small stuff like this.
Ah, I suppose not. Like robbing a bank and then parking in a disabled space. Right, we should get back to your ship. If that Scandroid is there, I want to take a look at it.
Glider lifts off.
Sampson, I told you not to start without me. What’s happening?
Priority information.
What did you do to him? Is he dead?
Priority information.
You’ve killed him!
Priority information.
Keep back.
Alarm sounds.
Priority information. Priority information.
How far is it now?
It’s moored behind that peak there. Here, put your hand on this.
What for?
ID scan. I need to register you as temporary staff, otherwise the security systems will automatically apprehend you as soon as you walk inside.
Ah. Done?
Yep. You shouldn’t have any problems now. Don’t cause any trouble. I’m responsible for you. I’m not getting any response to my hails.
Maybe they’re busy?
Lake? What’s going on?
The Scandroid linked up with Sampson and he just died.
What?
Impossible.
Where is it now?
In the hangar. We’ve locked down the doors.
Lock down the whole ship. Nobody’s to come in or leave until this is dealt with.
We haven't heard from anybody in the field for more than an hour, except Bridge.
Where is she?
She’s coming in to land now. In that hangar.
Glider lands.
So, who do we...
The hangar’s deserted.
Is that unusual?
Very. And the alarm.
Yes, we should check the ship, see if anybody needs help. Where’s the exit?
Down that corridor.
Priority information.
Oh! Is this the one?
I’ve no idea. They all look alike. Scandroid, who are you ass...
Priority information.
Why does he keep saying that?
If it’s behaving oddly, I’d say it’s the one we're looking for.
Priority information.
Well, let’s see what it’s got.
I’m not sure that’s wise. Tell it not to come any closer.
Scandroid, stop there.
Priority information.
The Doctor cries out.
What's it doing?
Oh! Oh! It’s trying to break my arm.
Scandroid, release him.
Prepare to receive priority information.
Get it off me!
It isn’t responding.
Prepare to receive priority information.
The Doctor screams.

parts.searchable_dialogue:
FEDERER: Progress.
SCANDROID: 233 new files located.
FEDERER: Link up. Let’s see them. Ow!
SCANDROID: Your dataport fully functional.
FEDERER: I thought so.
SCANDROID: The manufacturer of this hardware recommends that you lay your hand palm upwards when connecting.
FEDERER: Yes, I do know. Now shut up and get on with it.
FEDERER: Hi, this is Federer. Who’s there?
LAKE: [OC]: (a woman) It’s Lake. How are you getting on?
FEDERER: Really badly. There’s nothing in this quarter.
LAKE: [OC]: Nothing?
FEDERER: Nothing useful. Books, chat room archive, pictures of dogs dressed in bee costumes, bad poetry. Nothing secure. I’m just downloading it... ow!
SCANDROID: Exchange complete.
FEDERER: Delete and keep looking. Ow, that stings.
LAKE: [OC]: You all right?
FEDERER: I’m getting a stinging sensation in the skin around my dataport every time a Scandroid links into it.
LAKE: [OC]: You shouldn’t have installed it on the inside of your wrist. It’s too close to the nerves. I had mine moved to just below my elbow, and never had any trouble since.
FEDERER: Well, I’m coming back in a couple of minutes. Book me in with a cybertech and I'll see about doing that.
LAKE: [OC]: Give it another half hour, Fed. Marriott really seems to think there’s something in your sector.
FEDERER: Oh, I’ve been out here all day. What does he think I...
SCANDROID: This is priority information.
FEDERER: Oh. Oh, it looks like we’ve got something. I’ll call you back.
SCANDROID: Prepare to receive priority information.
FEDERER: Yeah, gimme... hey! Ow! No, stop it. Hey. (and other cries of discomfort, until thud.)
SCANDROID: (unintelligible under Federer’s cries until-) Information has not been delivered. Priority information. Priority information.
GABE: Munm,, that portmanteau case we found had an ID backup chip sewn in the lining.
DENISE: Oh yeah? Give it here. Gabe, this is a fake.
GABE: I know, but it looks a pretty good fake. We might be able to sell it on.
DENISE: I’m not risking selling a fake to a good contact.
GABE: Don’t sell it to one of the usual contacts. Sell it anonymous, cheap. Better than wasting it.
DENISE: You know that’s not how I like to work, Gabe.
GABE: We need to see something, Mum. Maybe we should shift to another sector before this one gets mined out.
DENISE: The Clinic won’t be here forever. We'll ride it out, and we won’t compromise our principles just because of them.
GABE: You’ve got principles?
DENISE: Don’t be funny. Just because we don’t always stick to them doesn’t mean they’re not worth having.
GABE: You just like thinking you’re better than them.
DENISE: Of course I do, because I am, and so are you.
GABE: Shh.
DENISE: What's that?
DENISE: Is it coming from that thing?
GABE: Yeah. I... There’s somebody in it.
DOCTOR: (distant) Hello! I’m the Doctor. I wonder if... oh, oh, oh. Ow! (and other cries of pain.)
GABE: Is he... dead?
DENISE: I don’t think so. Let’s get down there, see if he’s got anything.
GABE: Here, he said he was a doctor. Maybe he’s with the Clinic?
DENISE: Yeah. You bring him up. I'll hail the Clinic and see if we can get any cash out of them.
GABE: You’re gonna hold him to ransom?
DENISE: Course I am. That’s your problem, Gabe. No eye for an angle. Your father was the same. Now get down there and bring him up. And try and keep him in one piece.
LAKE: Fed? Are you there?
CLAUDIA: How long since you were last in contact, Lake?
LAKE: Twenty minutes, maybe? He couldn’t have got out of range.
MARRIOTT: No, of course not. Just watch. He’ll come back insisting his comm went dead. In the meantime, he’s slacking.
LAKE: I don’t think so, Doctor Marriott. The last time we spoke, his Scandroid had just found something. What if pirates have ‘napped him? Look, I really think
MARRIOTT: I don’t care what you think, Lake. I can read a personality, and I knew they’d dumped a slacker on me the second I saw that boy. This doesn’t look good.
CLAUDIA: Doesn't look good to who, exactly?
MARRIOTT: Tevez is arriving this afternoon.
CLAUDIA: They’re sending a company accountant? Why didn’t I hear about this?
MARRIOTT: You probably weren't listening, Bridge. And she’s the company accountant these days.
CLAUDIA: What happened to Nardini?
MARRIOTT: Disappeared, along with about 6 million Q. Tevez is in charge now, and I don’t want anyone looking like they’re wasting this project’s time and money.
LAKE: New voice message, Doctor Marriott.
DENISE: [OC]: We're holding one of your people. If you want him back, I’ve attached a map showing where to meet us. There’s a price, but I reckon you can afford it.
LAKE: Told you.
MARRIOTT: Tevez won't be impressed if we’re throwing away money on a replaceable resource like Federer. Where's the rendezvous?
LAKE: A derelict shack about two clicks north-east.
MARRIOTT: I’m assigning this one to you, Bridge. You’ve got a ransom budget of 5000.
CLAUDIA: They’ll want more than that.
MARRIOTT: Well, I’m not giving you more than that. If he can’t look after himself out there, that’s his problem. If they won’t deal, then just come back. He isn’t worth it.
CLAUDIA: Okay.
MARRIOTT: Oh, but try to find out what happened to his Scandroid. If there was anything on there, I want to see it. And try to get back here before Tevez
LAKE: She’s coming in to land now, Doctor Marriott.
MARRIOTT: (sigh) Signal to her that I'll be there asap. Just try to leave without her seeing you.
DENISE: Have you scanned him yet, Gabe?
GABE: The imprinter won't read him. I’m just getting a blank.
DENISE: Let me try.
GABE: See?
DENISE: Weird.
DOCTOR: Excuse me, madam. What are you doing?
DENISE: Be quiet and stay still.
DOCTOR: I’ve twisted my ankle. I’m just checking it’s not broken. Oof! Oh, ticklish, in an unpleasant way. That’s a device for taking an imprint of the human brain, I assume.
DENISE: Be quiet.
DOCTOR: Well, if you insist, but I can save you time by telling you it won’t work on me.
DENISE: Got an application in your skull to block it, have you?
GABE: Hey, we could use that.
DENISE: Tell us how it works and how to get it out, and we might let you live.
DOCTOR: Well, I think we can do without the threats. No, it’s not an application or a trick. My brain’s just... different.
DENISE: Really. My son here’s got a cross-wired brain too.
GABE: Don’t tell people that.
DOCTOR: What do you mean, cross-wired?
DENISE: He’s analogic. His brain can’t process digital.
DOCTOR: Digital? What, you mean direct digital input into the brain? Organic digital transfer?
DENISE: What else? Even the boy isn’t as hard of thinking as you.
GABE: Mum.
DOCTOR: Hmm. Even humanity didn’t develop a form of pure digital information that the brain could absorb until... well, this must be the 32” century.
GABE: I’m not sure he is with the Clinic.
DENISE: You never know, they might need the odd moron for experiments and so on.
DOCTOR: Madam, I am not a moron. Now who are you people?
GABE: I’m Gabe Stillinger.
DOCTOR: And this is your mother.
DENISE: Denise.
GABE: So what do we do with him?
DENISE: The Clinic signalled they were coming to meet us, so they must have someone missing.
GABE: I found some gadgets in his pockets.
DOCTOR: Oh, give those back.
DENISE: Oh, nice.
DOCTOR: You have no hope of understanding how to operate them.
DENISE: We don’t need to understand them to sell them, any more than we need to understand you to sell you.
DOCTOR: What?
DENISE: Tie him up. We should set off for the rendezvous
DOCTOR: Oh.
MARRIOTT: Mz Tevez. I hope you haven’t been waiting long.
TEVEZ: Nine minutes.
MARRIOTT: Is that long, in your opinion?
TEVAZ: I put it to good use. Can we walk and talk?
MARRIOTT: Certainly. I understand you’ve never been to the Valley before.
TEVEZ: Never had reason to. I haven’t had the time to research it either, so fill me in. How much material is there in the Valley?
MARRIOTT: This is only an estimate, but the Valley is twelve clicks from one extreme to the other, and it’s reckoned there are maybe four billion data storage devices here.
TEVEZ: Four billion?
MARRIOTT: With another sixty thousand items being dumped daily.
TEVEZ: What sort of material?
MARRIOTT: It ranges from the kind of chip you’d find in a refrigerator or a pet collar through to corporate hub systems. About eighty percent of it’s broken or stripped, but that still leaves a massive amount of recoverable data.
TEVEZ: What's the legal status?
MARRIOTT: It’s a policing nightmare, so it’s ideal, really. It was supposed to be part of a recycling programme that fell through decades ago. The authorities tried to keep quiet about it. You saw the floating homes on your way in?
TEVEZ: Yes?
MARRIOTT: Data pirates. They hold private sector recycling licences, and most of them trade the odd bit of junk for appearances’ sake, but it’s all about the data really.
TEVEZ: That’s got to make working here a little dangerous.
MARRIOTT: Oh, a little, yes.
CLAUDIA: Hello? It’s Claudia Bridge from the Clinic? You said you’d found one of our people.
DENISE: Shall we talk money?
CLAUDIA: Where is he?
DENISE: In the next room.
CLAUDIA: Let me see him first. How do I know he’s really here?
DENISE: Gabe, bring him out.
GABE: [OC]: Is she armed?
CLAUDIA: I am, yes.
GABE: [OC]: Have you got her covered, Mum?
DENISE: Of course.
DOCTOR: Oof! (thud) Ah, hello.
CLAUDIA: I’m sorry, what is this?
DENISE: Eight thousand if you want him back.
CLAUDIA: Who told you he was one of ours? Did he?
DOCTOR: I’ve never claimed to be anything I’m not.
GABE: No, but
DENISE: He’s not one of us. He must be with you.
CLAUDIA: He’s not.
DENISE: You might be bluffing, hoping we'll let him go anyway.
CLAUDIA: I’m not hoping anything. I’ve no idea who he is.
GABE: So why’d you come out here?
CLAUDIA: One of ours is missing, but this isn’t him.
DOCTOR: Really. Then perhaps
DENISE: Shut up. If you don’t start talking money then we'll kill him.
DOCTOR: Ah.
CLAUDIA: Go ahead. It’s more than my job’s worth to pay you for him. Actually, what am I still doing here?
DENISE: We’re not messing about. We will kill him.
CLAUDIA: (distant) Please, don’t waste our time again.
DENISE: Last chance!
DOCTOR: You appear to have missed.
DENISE: Well, it would have been pointless if I’d killed you and she’d come running back wailing, ‘stop, stop don’t kill him, I'll pay up’.
GABE: It’s pointless anyway.
DENISE: Worth a try. Anyway, we’ve got the stuff in his pockets.
DOCTOR: Er, what about me?
DENISE: What about you? (walks away)
DOCTOR: Oh. Oh, well, I’ll see myself out, then, shall I?
LAKE: [OC]: So who was he?
CLAUDIA: No idea. Just a wandering nutter. I’m going to have a scout around while I’m here, see if I can find Federer.
LAKE: [OC]: I’ll let you know if he checks in.
CLAUDIA: Okay. So, they didn’t kill you.
DOCTOR: Apparently not. I’m surprised you care enough to ask. Who are you?
CLAUDIA: Claudia Bridge.
DOCTOR: Charmed to meet you. I’m the Doctor.
CLAUDIA: No hard feelings, but I wasn’t lying. I could never have cleared the funds to bring in a non-staff member.
DOCTOR: You’d have stood by and let another person die because you couldn’t clear the funds?
CLAUDIA: What else could I have done?
DOCTOR: Oh, helped me, perhaps? Did the moral centre of the universe shift whilst I was unconscious? Where am I, anyway? Looks like an enormous junk yard.
CLAUDIA: Obsoletion Valley, where old computers come to die.
DOCTOR: So it is an enormous junk yard. How appallingly wasteful.
CLAUDIA: If you don’t know that, how did you get here?
DOCTOR: Oh, I arrived in my ship. It’s just over... (effort) Oh, where’s it gone?
CLAUDIA: Stolen, probably. The pirates here will take anything.
DOCTOR: Oh.
CLAUDIA: Sorry.
DOCTOR: Oh, whoops. Er, the er hover-platform. Is that your transports?
CLAUDIA: Hover-platform? You talk like someone from the Republican Era. Yes, this is my glider.
DOCTOR: Ah. Would you like some help looking for your friend?
CLAUDIA: Not friend, colleague. And how can you possibly help? Thirty seconds ago you didn’t even know where you were.
DOCTOR: Answer me this. What’s happened to him?
CLAUDIA: I don’t know.
DOCTOR: An unexplained disappearance, then.
CLAUDIA: I wouldn’t say
DOCTOR: Explain it, then.
CLAUDIA: What's your point?
DOCTOR: The unexplained is my speciality.
CLAUDIA: You just want to tag along to find this ship of yours.
DOCTOR: Yes. But I want to help as well.
CLAUDIA: Well, all right. Just don’t annoy me.
DOCTOR: Oh, I’m sure I can manage that.
CLAUDIA: Don’t be too confident. I’m very easily annoyed.
MAN: Stop! Stop! What have you got? Ah!
SCANDROID: 2: What are you doing?
SCANDROID: I have priority information. These pirates were attempting to hijack it.
SCANDROID: 2: Do you need assistance?
SCANDROID: No. But I must share data with you.
SCANDROID: 2: Contact. Share data. Priority information.
SCANDROID: I am returning to the Clinic to deliver this information.
SCANDROID: 2: I will deliver the information to my operator.
SCANDROIDS: (stomping away) Priority information.
DOCTOR: This is a bracing way to travel.
CLAUDIA: It’s supposed to have a wind resistance filter, but it doesn’t seem to work.
DOCTOR: Oh, I don’t mind.
CLAUDIA: You will after you swallow your first insect.
DOCTOR: (laughs) They said you were here with a clinic. Are you a medic?
CLAUDIA: No, I’m a researcher and a Scandroid technician. We're out looking for materials.
DOCTOR: What clinic gets materials from a place like this?
CLAUDIA: We specialise in personality surgery.
DOCTOR: Personality sur... You mean artificially altering people’s personalities to order?
CLAUDIA: Mmm hmm. You must have heard of that, surely.
DOCTOR: Oh, I’ve a very good grounding in the principles. But hold on. You get your materials from here? You’re using real people’s personal details?
CLAUDIA: Yes.
DOCTOR: People leave that sort of thing lying around?
CLAUDIA: People are careless. Say they leave a backup brain print on their home system in case they have an accident, then say they buy a new system and don’t delete everything off the old one before chucking it. We find it and use it.
DOCTOR: So you’re letting people impersonate other people? Letting your clients steal other people’s identities?
CLAUDIA: That’s not all we do. Alot of our business is purely aesthetic.
DOCTOR: Aesthetic?
CLAUDIA: Most clients just want to change an aspect of themselves they’re dissatisfied with, but for the right price we will give somebody another person’s full personality.
DOCTOR: That’s never been legal.
CLAUDIA: No? Sorry, it sounds as if you object.
DOCTOR: I most certainly do. It’s immoral. It’s criminal.
CLAUDIA: We stay just the right side of legal. We also look for redundant material where the legal status isn’t an issue. It provides inspiration for a lot of the aesthetic work.
DOCTOR: Ha.
CLAUDIA: No, really. A lot of people come to us looking for a more... retro aspect to their personality. People who rail against it just don’t understand it.
DOCTOR: I understand it only too well. Probably better than you do. Oh, I’d forgotten what a decadent age this is.
CLAUDIA: Then you must have a terrible memory. Everybody who can afford it has work done.
DOCTOR: Have you?
CLAUDIA: Only a little. I got it when I started at the Clinic.
DOCTOR: And you regret it?
CLAUDIA: If I did, I'd ask for my money back. It’s designed to stop me regretting things. Keeps my conscience in check.
DOCTOR: Oh, look down there. That’s my ship.
CLAUDIA: The blue thing?
DOCTOR: Yes, the blue thing.
CLAUDIA: I'll take us down.
MARRIOTT: Did you want lactose and saccharin, Mz Tevez?
TEVEZ: Just black, thank you. You’ve clearly been working hard out here, Marriott.
MARRIOTT: Thank you.
TEVEZ: But it’s not enough to balance the cost. The risk factor has pushed up the budget twenty two percent. There are more efficient ways of achieving comparable results.
MARRIOTT: But we’re within profit margins.
TEVEZ: Barely. And it doesn’t address the fact we could make bigger profits by more conventional means.
MARRIOTT: You haven’t taken into account what this project could produce in the future.
TEVEZ: I don’t see anything that justifies the expenditure.
MARRIOTT: That’s because I haven't told you the real reason for coming here.
TEVEZ: And that is?
MARRIOTT: I don’t suppose you’d take it on trust that it’s a good reason?
TEVEZ: He said it was a good idea and I believed him. It won’t play well on my report. You’re a talented surgeon, Marriott. People are asking why you’re spending so much here, and so little operating back at your branch.
MARRIOTT: All right, then. I'll tell you.
CLAUDIA: Is this really a vehicle?
DOCTOR: Yes.
CLAUDIA: Looks like these guys here were trying to cart it away.
DOCTOR: Yes. No pulse. He’s dead. Been pretty badly beaten as well.
CLAUDIA: Urgh, looks like the other one’s dead too. Probably got attacked by raiders.
DOCTOR: So why didn’t they take anything? The Tardis is still here and look, their bags are loaded. There’s plenty to steal.
CLAUDIA: Well, since we’ve found your ship, you can get on your way, can’t you?
DOCTOR: Hmm? No, not yet. I promised to help you find your colleague.
CLAUDIA: You really don’t have to. What is that?
DOCTOR: A telescope.
CLAUDIA: Looks like an antique. Careful you don’t let it out of your
DOCTOR: Ah ha.
CLAUDIA: What?
DOCTOR: I think I see something. About half a kilometre away. Come on.
CLAUDIA: Hang on. Let’s take the glider.
DOCTOR: Nonsense, Claudia. No harm in a little exercise. Come on, don’t shilly-shally. Keep up.
TEVEZ: Zachary Kindell?
MARRIOTT: I know what you’re going to say.
TEVEZ: That he was a volatile, immoral egotist?
MARRIOTT: Actually, I didn’t think you’d phrase it exactly like that.
TEVEZ: But I’m not wrong, am I?
MARRIOTT: No, but I think we could still learn a lot by finding his research. Maybe now the world would be ready, rather than trying to hammer the genie back into the bottle.
TEVEZ: There’s no evidence of any significant advances he made that we don’t already know about.
MARRIOTT: A man like that doesn’t just stop having ideas.
TEVEZ: He might, if he tinkered with his brain one too many times.
MARRIOTT: He’d have made backup copies of his mind, though, surely. I mean, we could even bring him back.
TEVEZ: You think he’s here?
MARRIOTT: It’s possible, but I don’t think so. But I do think some of his projects are. It isn’t guesswork. I’ve been trying to trace this material for years. Let me show you.
CLAUDIA: Doctor, slow down.
DOCTOR: Hmm? Barely going at a canter. You must be out of shape. Ah. Is this him, Claudia?
CLAUDIA: Yep, that’s Fed.
DOCTOR: I’m afraid he’s dead. Oh, I’m sorry, I didn’t intend that to rhyme. It’s hardly an appropriate time. Oh, good grief, I’ve done it again.
CLAUDIA: What’s happened to him?
DOCTOR: I don’t know.
CLAUDIA: I thought you said you were a doctor.
DOCTOR: There’s not a mark on him. No evidence of heart failure.
CLAUDIA: Let’s just get him back to the glider. One of the medics at the ship will know. That’s odd.
DOCTOR: I know. I really can’t
CLAUDIA: I mean it’s odd that his Scandroid isn’t here.
DOCTOR: Scandroid?
CLAUDIA: We use them to dig through all the tech and scan the storage units for material. But if its operator dies, it’s meant to signal the ship and wait with the body.
DOCTOR: Well, it hasn't. Is there any circumstance under which it wouldn’t do that? And if there was, what would it do instead?
PIRATE: Junk, junk, out of date.
PIRATE: Hello, what are you up to?
SCANDROID: Criminal grade, data pirate. You are not authorised for interaction. Do not impede me.
PIRATE: Ah, wait a second.
SCANDROID: If you continue to impede me, I will be forced to use violence.
PIRATE: Well, then I'll be forced to use this.
SCANDROID: That dis-disabling device is illegal. The Lonway Clinic will be displeased by your actions.
PIRATE: Oh, you’re the Clinic, are you? Well, let’s see what you’ve got.
SCANDROID: You are not authorised... to access my data.
PIRATE: Will be in a second. Just tweaking your protocols, mate. Hang on a bit. Now, how’d you feel about handing that stuff over?
SCANDROID: Prepare to receive priority information.
PIRATE: That sounds good. Let’s see it, then. Ah! Oh! Ow! Disengage! Disen... argh. (thud)
SCANDROID: Information has not been delivered. (receding)Priority information.
TEVEZ: Hmm. It’s more interesting than I expected.
MARRIOTT: So you'll recommend it?
TEVEZ: I didn’t say that. Even if you find this material, we have no idea of its value. Any breakthroughs Kindell made will be decades old. They've probably been surpassed.
MARRIOTT: I don’t believe that.
TEVEZ: Well, this isn’t a debating society. But you can rest assured I’m looking on this enterprise more charitably.
MARRIOTT: Yes, Marriott.
LAKE: [OC]: We’ve just spotted Federer’s Scandroid outside on its way back. No sign of him, though.
MARRIOTT: Download whatever it’s got. I’ll be down in a second.
LAKE: [OC]: I’ll tell Sampson to get onto it.
TEVEZ: What's this?
MARRIOTT: What? Oh, nothing important. One of our people’s late reporting in. I'll be back shortly. Feel free to
TEVEZ: I'll come with you.
MARRIOTT: Oh. Yes. Well, feel free.
TEVEZ: Thank you. I do. Lead on.
DOCTOR: Another body.
CLAUDIA: Data pirate. The same as Federer?
DOCTOR: Yes. No sign of what’s happened to him. Just dead.
CLAUDIA: He’s definitely just seen a Scandroid.
DOCTOR: Why? Does he have a ‘just seen a Scandroid’ expression on his face?
CLAUDIA: No, that’s what this device is for. Disabling Scandroids. And it’s been discharged recently.
DOCTOR: Oh, let me take a look at it. An. So, where’s the Scandroid if he disabled it?
CLAUDIA: Oh, the effect doesn’t last long. It’s very crude.
DOCTOR: Do you have any of these?
CLAUDIA: No, we don’t. They’re illegal.
DOCTOR: I fail to see how those two facts are connected.
CLAUDIA: It’s not worth drawing attention to yourself with small stuff like this.
DOCTOR: Ah, I suppose not. Like robbing a bank and then parking in a disabled space. Right, we should get back to your ship. If that Scandroid is there, I want to take a look at it.
LAKE: Sampson, I told you not to start without me. What’s happening?
SCANDROID: Priority information.
LAKE: What did you do to him? Is he dead?
SCANDROID: Priority information.
LAKE: You’ve killed him!
SCANDROID: Priority information.
LAKE: Keep back.
SCANDROID: Priority information. Priority information.
DOCTOR: How far is it now?
CLAUDIA: It’s moored behind that peak there. Here, put your hand on this.
DOCTOR: What for?
CLAUDIA: ID scan. I need to register you as temporary staff, otherwise the security systems will automatically apprehend you as soon as you walk inside.
DOCTOR: Ah. Done?
CLAUDIA: Yep. You shouldn’t have any problems now. Don’t cause any trouble. I’m responsible for you. I’m not getting any response to my hails.
DOCTOR: Maybe they’re busy?
MARRIOTT: Lake? What’s going on?
LAKE: The Scandroid linked up with Sampson and he just died.
TEVEZ: What?
MARRIOTT: Impossible.
TEVEZ: Where is it now?
LAKE: In the hangar. We’ve locked down the doors.
MARRIOTT: Lock down the whole ship. Nobody’s to come in or leave until this is dealt with.
LAKE: We haven't heard from anybody in the field for more than an hour, except Bridge.
MARRIOTT: Where is she?
LAKE: She’s coming in to land now. In that hangar.
DOCTOR: So, who do we...
LAKE: The hangar’s deserted.
DOCTOR: Is that unusual?
LAKE: Very. And the alarm.
DOCTOR: Yes, we should check the ship, see if anybody needs help. Where’s the exit?
LAKE: Down that corridor.
SCANDROID: Priority information.
DOCTOR: Oh! Is this the one?
LAKE: I’ve no idea. They all look alike. Scandroid, who are you ass...
SCANDROID: Priority information.
LAKE: Why does he keep saying that?
DOCTOR: If it’s behaving oddly, I’d say it’s the one we're looking for.
SCANDROID: Priority information.
LAKE: Well, let’s see what it’s got.
DOCTOR: I’m not sure that’s wise. Tell it not to come any closer.
LAKE: Scandroid, stop there.
SCANDROID: Priority information.
LAKE: What's it doing?
DOCTOR: Oh! Oh! It’s trying to break my arm.
LAKE: Scandroid, release him.
SCANDROID: Prepare to receive priority information.
DOCTOR: Get it off me!
LAKE: It isn’t responding.
SCANDROID: Prepare to receive priority information.

elements.text: [Part Two]
You are not equipped with a standard data-sharing port.
Oh, thank goodness for that!
Prepare for short-range direct broadcast. Buffering. Please wait.
Claudia, use the disabling device.
I haven't got it.
It’s in my pocket. Oh!
Disabling device is illegal.
Quickly, wipe its memory.
But Doctor Marriott...
Do it, I say!
Okay. I need to get through the back panel. That should do it.
Reset to factory default settings is in progress.
Thank you.
[OC]: Bridge, what have you done to it?
Doctor Marriott, where are you?
[OC]: Watching you on the monitors.
You know, some small assistance might have been appreciated in here.
[OC]: What are you doing?
Wiping its memory.
[OC]: I thought so, but I didn’t quite believe you'd be that irresponsible. Stop it.
I’m sorry, sir, but the Doctor here said that I
[OC]: I don’t care what he said. Who is he?
Me! And if we don’t erase that Scandroid’s data, it’ll most likely kill us all. Claudia, finish the job.
[OC]: It might be carrying valuable information. It should be thoroughly debriefed first.
I don’t see you leaping in here to do that.
[OC]: Of course not. That’s what the others are paid for.
Memory reset complete. Reinstalling standard software.
I’m sorry, Doctor Marriott.
[OC]: Pah. I’m lifting the lock-down, but you haven’t heard the last of this, Bridge.
Priority information. Priority information.
Where’s its operator?
Who cares? Have you got a clear shot at it yet?
Not yet, Mum.
Hurry up, Gabe.
Shh. Give us a chance. (shot fired) Yes.
(slower) Priority information.
Tough, aren’t they? Give it another blast. I'll get in close and use the disabler.
Shot fired.
Go, go, go.
Stay covered.
Priority (powers down.)
Come on. Give me a hand getting it up to the home. Let’s see what it’s got.
At last, I can hear myself think. Lake, did you get anything from the Scandroid before it attacked you?
No, but it did say it had priority information.
Why didn’t it just broadcast the information back here?
We don’t broadcast if we can help it. Too much risk of data being intercepted. Anything of importance would be delivered in person.
Like
Yes, Mz Tevez. Like the item we discussed.
We traced the Scandroid’s movements. It encountered two other Scandroids on its way here and shared data with both.
Oh.
So we tracked their movements too. They came into contact with others and, well, that covers all of the researchers currently in the field, and
What?
We can’t raise anybody. It’s dead out there.
Here, in my office. Lake, what about the Scandroids?
They’re not responding to remote control at all, but they’re mostly heading this way.
Mostly? What are the others doing?
You are not authorised to access my data.
Give it another zap with that thing.
Scandroid powers down.
I don’t know how much charge we’ve got left in this. I used a lot on the way up here. How are you getting on?
Nearly there.
Prepare to receive priority information.
And there it is. Come on, what’s
What is it?
I don’t know. It’s er... Turn it off. Gabe, make it stop!
How?
Denise screams, thud.
Mum? Mum!
Information not delivered
You killed her! You... ow!
Prepare to receive priority information.
I can’t, won't.
You are not equipped with a standard data sharing port.
No, I’m analogic.
Prepare for short-range direct broadcast. Buffering. Please wait.
I’m analogic, you stupid thing. I won’t be able to...
Information delivered.
I can’t understand the information.
Awaiting your instructions.
Shut up!
Understood.
Oh my. What did you do to her?
You're not in control here, are you, Marriott.
The Scandroids are doing exactly as instructed.
Aside from the part when they kill people.
Only one of them has done that. It’s probably a mechanical fault or something.
This is all going in my report, so just to be clear, are you seriously claiming that some kind of glitch? It just depends how stupid you want to look in retrospect.
Door opens and closes.
Doctor Marriott, is the ship gone off lock-down?
Yes, most of the Scandroids are returning.
Surely that’s a reason to keep the lock-down in place.
Those Scandroids are carrying vital information. I programmed them to behave this way only when they’d found something relating to our key objective.
Are you insane? Your Scandroids have been compromised. Something out there has turned them into killers. We found four dead bodies out there. Four!
I’m sorry, who is this man, Bridge?
He’s the one those pirates were holding. The one we assumed was Federer.
Right. And how does this explain why he’s here now?
You cannot let those Scandroids inside.
He’s right. The fact that you’ve lost contact with all your researchers in the field strongly suggests they’ve suffered the same fate as your technician.
You've lost contact with everybody in the field?
Tevez, that fact is not for general consumption. Bridge, if you tell anybody that, then I will have you kicked off this project.
Huh. That’s sounding less like a threat as time goes on.
So not only have you endangered everybody, you’re not even letting them know how danger they’re in!
I’ve seen enough. We’re abandoning this project. The human resources cost is already unacceptably high.
No.
You'll never work in this industry again if you don’t listen to me. In fact, you may never do anything again.
If I listen to you, I'll throw away the biggest advance this industry has seen maybe ever.
Oh, don’t be stupid.
I'll get what I want, and then it'll be me who makes sure you never work again. Any of you.
Door opens.
Hold on, what did I do?
The Scandroid, Bridge. In the hangar.
Oh yes.
Right.
Door closes.
Can you relieve him of command?
No. I’m an accountant. I can only cut off his funding. I can do it pretty ruthlessly, though.
It’s his project. He’s in control of the whole ship.
I might be able to get clearance from our superior, if I can get in touch with the office.
Please try. I’m going to see if I can reason with Marriott.
Door opens and closes.
Who exactly is he? You didn’t explain.
I’m not sure I can.
How many Scandroids are there out there.
Nine.
Nine? Let one in, tell the others to stay outside.
Doors open.
Just one, I said.
They’re not responding. Argh!
Get out of here! Everybody, get out!
Priority information.
Close the doors!
Marriott? Marriott.
I’m warning you.
Likewise. Only in my case it’s for your own good.
Lake, what are you doing?
It’s the same as before. One of the Scandroids linked up with Barros and killed him.
I still don’t understand. Killed him how?
He just died! We locked the doors behind us, but they opened them again. How are they doing that?
Technically, Lake, right now they outrank you.
But do they outrank you?
No.
Then close the doors, for heaven’s sake.
Prepare to receive priority information.
I’ve got something that will disable it. Temporarily, at least. Catch.
Where’d you get the disabler from? Those things cause serious corruption
Fall back. The effect doesn’t last long. Lock them out when we get through the next door.
You can’t poss...
Do you really want to die?
Everyone, back behind that door.
Prepare to receive priority information.
Get back, quickly!
Another man screams and dies. Doors close.
Thank you, Marriott.
So?
Can’t get hold of anybody to give me clearance. I’ve served notice of the problem, though.
So what next?
Door opens.
How are the Scandroids killing? Is it possible that they’re electrocuting people?
Well, of course it’s possible. They don’t run on magic. They’d have to be substantially modified.
Door closes.
You didn’t programme them to do this, did you? To protect your precious data?
No, no.
Sorry to interrupt, but are we safe now?
Relatively. But the Scandroids are between us and the exits, and we lost the disabler, I’m afraid.
That was stupid.
Yes. It was terribly stupid of the person who was using it to let themselves be killed so carelessly.
Calm down. Oh, can’t we shut the Scandroids down from here?
No, that’s been overridden. They can’t be shut down until they’ve delivered the data.
I’m sure this all made sense to you at the time.
It was simply to guarantee delivery.
So what else does this new programming involve?
Yes, do the Scandroids also become miraculously bullet-proof?
Well, actually, they’re already impervious to most conventional weapons.
Oh, marvellous.
The Scandroid is to deliver the data to the nearest authorised person. It should copy the data to any other Scandroids it encounters; and the data unlocks an elite access code.
Couldn’t we de-authorise ourselves and try to slip past?
No. If we do that, the ship’s security systems will think we’re intruders and apprehend us.
Couldn't we disable the security systems?
Not from here, and not easily.
And if the Scandroids perceive a threat, they’re programmed to resist by any means necessary.
So they might resort to violence.
Only where unauthorised personnel are concerned. I can’t account for what’s happening now.
Ah. Now this is starting to make sense.
Really?
Yes. It beat up the first two pirates Claudia and I found, but the third must have hacked it, received the data.
Nonsense. They don’t have the expertise.
Of course they do. Don’t underestimate them.
I thought the Scandroids must have been reprogrammed, but no. They’re just trying to deliver the data as instructed. But the data itself is the killer.
How can data kill you?
Well, if I'm right, anybody who knows that will be dead.
Come on, pick up the

[OC]: Yes.

[OC]: I’m afraid I really don’t
[OC]: Give me that, Lake. Hello? Who is this.

Here.

Certain frequencies used in tandem can disrupt the areas of the brain that absorb this information.

[OC]: Right. We'll go and tackle those when I’m done here.
Hello?
[OC]: Stillinger? It’s Doctor Marriott here. Are you still on your way?
