TEVEZ: I’ve got a notebook.
DOCTOR: Ah, that’s fine. Set it to download, and I'll turn this on, and let me know when you can’t understand it anymore.
TEVEZ: Right. Connecting now.
DOCTOR: Switching on. Anything yet?
TEVEZ: I'll tell you.
CLAUDIA: Doctor, are you sure that
TEVEZ: That’s it! That’s it!
DOCTOR: Definitely?
TEVEZ: Yes. I’m not getting anything at all. Wow! It’s strange, like being deaf.
DOCTOR: Excellent.
MARRIOTT: Wait. You’re really going out there?
DOCTOR: Yes. It only needs one.
CLAUDIA: Wait. How do we know that you’re not just going to skip out when you’re past the Scandroids?
DOCTOR: Because I’m not that sort of fellow. Wish me luck.
LAKE: Yes?
MARRIOTT: [OC]: Lake, someone’s coming to your door. Tell me when he reaches you. I'll release the door then lock it behind him.
LAKE: I think this might be him.
DOCTOR: Yes, it is me. You might want to stand back.
MARRIOTT: [OC]: Ready?
DOCTOR: Yes.
SCANDROID: Priority information.
DOCTOR: Close the door.
SCANDROID: Priority information.
DOCTOR: Hello.
SCANDROID: You are not equipped with a standard data sharing port.
DOCTOR: No.
SCANDROID: Prepare for short-range direct broadcast. Buffering. Please wait. Prepare to receive priority information.
DOCTOR: I’m ready.
SCANDROID: Information delivered. Awaiting your instructions.
SCANDROID: 2: Prepare to receive priority information.
DOCTOR: Oh. You too.
SCANDROID: 2: You are not equipped with a standard data sharing port. Prepare for short-range direct broadcast. Buffering.
DOCTOR: Oh. This could take a while.
SCANDROID: 2: Please wait.
TEVEZ: Doctor? Is it working?
DOCTOR: [OC]: Yes. Immediately they’ve delivered they go into standby, but I’m wiping their memories as I go to be safe.
MARRIOTT: What?
TEVEZ: Good work. You will be well rewarded for this.
MARRIOTT: You’re going to reward him for sabotaging...
TEVEZ: Your quarters is clear of Scandroids, Marriott. Why don’t you go and start packing?
MARRIOTT: I’ll go, but grr.
DOCTOR: [OC]: I don’t want a reward.
CLAUDIA: How many Scandroids are left?
DOCTOR: [OC]: Four, maybe five, here.
CLAUDIA: Well, they seem to have flocked towards you. We’ve been able to seal off most of the lower deck, but I think there’s more at the opposite end in reception.
DOCTOR: [OC]: Right. We'll go and tackle those when I’m done here.
GABE: Hello?
MARRIOTT: [OC]: Stillinger? It’s Doctor Marriott here. Are you still on your way?
GABE: I’m in a holding pattern. I don’t want to come too close. Is it safe yet?
MARRIOTT: [OC]: I'll clear you to land when it is.
GABE: So you want to buy back the Scandroid. How much for?
MARRIOTT: [OC]: We can talk about that when you’re here. But it’s the data I want. Download it onto one of your old physical interface computers and bring it directly to me.
GABE: Right you are.
SCANDROID: Information delivered. Awaiting your instructions.
DOCTOR: Is that the last one?
CLAUDIA: All the ones on board the ship. There may be more still out there, though.
CLAUDIA: Are you resetting it?
DOCTOR: Of course.
CLAUDIA: Shouldn't we take a look at one of them first?
DOCTOR: Why? In case they're carrying something valuable?
CLAUDIA: No, to work out how we can stop this happening again.
DOCTOR: All right. But we show nobody else. And we need to work on a computer that doesn’t operate via organic digital transfer.
CLAUDIA: Why don’t you just call it ODT like everyone else?
DOCTOR: Do you have such a computer?
CLAUDIA: Of course not.
DOCTOR: Then it’s too dangerous.
GABE: Oh. Hello again.
CLAUDIA: What are you doing here?
GABE: Returning your Scandroid.
DOCTOR: Where is it?
GABE: Outside, in the home.
CLAUDIA: I'll get a couple of our people to bring it inside.
GABE: Hey, hey, I haven’t agreed a price yet, and I’m not letting any of your lot in there alone.
DOCTOR: Oh, so a Scandroid kills your mother and your first thought is how much you can sell it for.
GABE: Not my first thought. And if Mum was here she’d give me and earful for that. Always look for the angle, she used to say.
CLAUDIA: Well, here’s another. You use old-style computers, don’t you? The sort you have to talk to and touch the screen?
GABE: Yeah. What about it?
CLAUDIA: Want to rent one out to us?
GABE: All right. 50 Q.
CLAUDIA: Fine.
GABE: Per hour.
CLAUDIA: Per hour?
DOCTOR: That's all we'll need it for.
GABE: There you go. Mind you don’t wipe anything. (leaves)
DOCTOR: Pass that over here.
CLAUDIA: When did you take charge?
DOCTOR: Oh, a while ago. Didn’t you notice?
MARRIOTT: What's going on out there?
GABE: [OC]: It’s me. Gabe Stillinger.
MARRIOTT: What are you thumping on my door for?
GABE: [OC]: I can’t use your buzzer. It’s the analogia. I can’t use anything on this ship. Can you let me in?
MARRIOTT: Did anyone see you?
GABE: A couple of people, but they’re all pretty busy with the clearing up and that.
MARRIOTT: Good. So how much do you want for the data?
GABE: Right. Shall we say, I dunno, 80,000 Q?
MARRIOTT: Yes, fine.
GABE: Oh, well.
MARRIOTT: Well what? You are selling it, aren’t you?
GABE: Er, yeah.
MARRIOTT: Here’s a transfer chip for 80,000.
GABE: There’s the data. Er, I could do with getting that system back when you’ve taken the data off it. They're not that easy to get hold of.
MARRIOTT: Oh, it’s like one of those old touch-screens.
GABE: You use the stylus there and
MARRIOTT: Yes, I Know. Good grief, these are awkward.
GABE: They’re all right when you get used to them.
MARRIOTT: Why don’t you get that condition seen to?
GABE: Could never afford it. Can now.
MARRIOTT: Now, what do we have.
CLAUDIA: Oh, Mz Tevez.
TEVEZ: I still haven’t been able to get in touch with them at the office. But when I get there I’m going to have them transfer authority over this ship to you.
CLAUDIA: Me?
TEVEZ: Yes, you. You seem level-headed enough.
DOCTOR: Oh, her head never strays from the level.
TEVEZ: All you have to do is pack up and take it back, simple enough. I'll be in my shuttle preparing to leave if you need me.
DOCTOR: Good grief. Come here. Look. Do you know what this does?
CLAUDIA: Personality recode data. Sorry, I’m not a surgeon.
DOCTOR: Well, this part here is a series of checks and balances to allow the programme to run itself.
CLAUDIA: Run itself?
DOCTOR: Yes. Doesn’t have to be supervised. It rewrites the brain as soon as its downloaded.
CLAUDIA: Well, that’s ridiculously dangerous. You need to know the pattern of the brain before you start moving things around.
DOCTOR: According to this map, the programme targets the autonomous brain. The part that makes you breathe regularly and so on? And wipes it clean.
CLAUDIA: It makes you forget how to breathe? I’ve never heard of anything like that before.
DOCTOR: Nor have I, and I don’t want to ever again. So...
CLAUDIA: You’ve deleted it.
DOCTOR: Yes. But there’s more.
MARRIOTT: Ah ha. I knew it.
GABE: Knew what?
MARRIOTT: Tevez didn’t think he’d have achieved anything new, but this is revolutionary stuff. Auto-surgery.
GABE: But it killed people.
MARRIOTT: Oh, it was designed to. But there are conventional applications for the same technology.
GABE: So why use it to kill people?
MARRIOTT: Look at how the files are stored. This is the deadly one, here, but the main file is underneath it. The way they’re linked makes it impossible to open the main one without opening the one that kills you.
GABE: So unless you know what to expect, and open it up on a system like mine or something...
MARRIOTT: You die. Clever. And I’d programmed the Scandroids to deliver the data at all costs, so that’s what they did. I hadn’t thought of that. Still, live and learn.
GABE: I still don’t understand. Why make it kill people?
MARRIOTT: The man who designed this is long dead, but he left behind copies of his research, and he didn’t want anyone else to get their hands on it, so he set up a trap.
GABE: But what good is it to anyone if he’s dead?
MARRIOTT: It might be good for him, if he comes back.
TEVEZ: Lake? This is Tevez. How long before you can clear me for take-off?
LAKE: [OC]: I think we’ve got a damaged stabiliser. Sorry, we need to run a check. Twenty minutes or so?
TEVEZ: Right. I'll come back inside to wait.
SCANDROID: Priority information.
TEVEZ: Lake, there’s a Scandroid in here.
SCANDROID: Prepare to receive priority information.
LAKE: [OC]: Mz Tevez?
SCANDROID: Information delivered. Awaiting your instructions.
LAKE: [OC]: Mz Tevez, are you all right?
TEVEZ: Are you speaking to me?
LAKE: [OC]: Yes. Are you all right?
TEVEZ: Yes. Yes, I’m fine.
LAKE: [OC]: Is the Scandroid (cut off)
TEVEZ: Scandroid, did you deliver the programme to me?
SCANDROID: Yes.
TEVEZ: Make me a copy of that programme. Do you know where I am?
SCANDROID: Yes.
TEVEZ: Tell me about it.
GABE: You sure it’s safe to do that?
MARRIOTT: Perfectly safe. I’ve deleted the dangerous file. I’m just importing the main data, and then you can have this back. There.
GABE: Thanks.
MARRIOTT: Now what is... Oh, wonderful.
GABE: What is it?
MARRIOTT: (voice distorting) Please, leave me. Alone. I’m trying to...
GABE: Doctor Marriott?
MARRIOTT: I... I’m trying to... concentrate. Leave.
GABE: What’s
MARRIOTT: Leave.
DOCTOR: Oh, this is alarming.
CLAUDIA: What is it?
DOCTOR: You don’t need to know. I’m deleting it. Good riddance. But if you find any other copies.
GABE: (distant) Doctor? Doctor?
CLAUDIA: Gabe, what’s happened out there?
GABE: It’s Marriott. I just sold him some data...
DOCTOR: Not the data from the Scandroid you found?
GABE: Yes.
DOCTOR: Oh, you idiot!
CLAUDIA: Is he dead?
DOCTOR: No, I think it’s likely to be worse than that.
GABE: He reckons the part of it that kills people was just a cover.
DOCTOR: Yes, we know.
GABE: Oh. Well, it’s the other part he’s going through at the moment. He seems to be... changing.
DOCTOR: Yes, he will be. Like the first one, it works automatically. Feeds itself straight into your brain and gets to work. But it doesn’t just change your mind.
CLAUDIA: What does it do?
DOCTOR: It changes a lot more than that. Was he in here?
GABE: Yeah.
DOCTOR: I hope we’re not too late to stop him.
CLAUDIA: Too late?
DOCTOR: Yes.
MARRIOTT: Die, scum. Grr.

elements.text: [Part Three]
Close the door!
Marriott opened the door. He’s still control.
It doesn’t look like him.
Run!
(roar) Stop!
The major holdings of the Lonway Clinic are
Skip that part.
What other areas of the L...
What? What other areas of what?
Scum.
Scum? Who’s scum?
All scum. Unworthy. Tiny minds. Scum. Stupid. Destroy. Scum.
Whoosh.
You could have killed me!
Destroy scum.
Oh. And you meant it. Stay. Don’t follow.
Must follow and destroy scum.
Get the doors open!
I just hope he hasn’t locked them down.
Door opens.
Mz Tevez, we thought you’d gone.
I wouldn’t come in here. Something’s happened to Marriott.
I wouldn’t go out there either. One of your robots has gone berserk.
Berserk?
(nearby) Destroy scum.
It’s Marriott. He’s using the Scandroids against us.
How?
The hangar.
Yes. Come on.
What happened to Marriott?
The programme he accessed not only changed his mind, it enabled his mind to reshape his body.
Seriously?
Seriously.
Why change yourself into that?
The programme isn’t finished. There’s a mutation in it which I assume the creator couldn’t resolve.
That was close. Very close.
What?
Hey!
Lake, where did you just come from?
The hangar. What’s going on? The Scandroid
Look out!
Destroy scum.
Lake screams.
Oh! Gabe, help me get her away.
She’s had it.
Don’t argue!
Destroy scum.
Got her. Look out.
Ah, it missed us.
Everyone, in here.
What’s in there?
No Scandroids. Come on.
Door closes.
Hey, that’s my computer. What are you doing with it?
Patching it into the ship’s systems and locking the door.
That won’t work. Marriott’s still controlling the doors.
Then I'll have to be more persuasive than him.
How come the ship still recognises that thing as Marriott?

As far as something like the ship’s concerned, living things are always changing. It saw him change, it adjusted its view accordingly. That’s the trouble with artificial intelligences. Far too smart, just when you don’t want them to be. There. Thank you for the use of this, Gabe. I have to say, I prefer to do these things by hand.
Will it open again?
Could there be more gratitude for us being safe, please?
Safely trapped in a tiny room.
How’s Lake?
She’s dead.
Well, there you are. It could be worse. We could be dead, like poor Lake.
He’s not wrong.
You seem a little different, Mz Tevez. I can’t quite put my finger on how.
My name isn’t Tevez.
Who are you, then?
Doctor Zachary Kindell.
Hello, master.
Where scum?
Scum are inside. The door is locked.
Open.
The door is locked.
Open. Open. Grr.
Can it get through that?
Hopefully not. They’re very strong, but very stupid.
What is that thing?
Just a mutant. My best result, unfortunately.
I'd hate to see the bad ones. Though I’m grudgingly impressed by your auto-surgery programme. I assume that was how you hijacked Mz Tevez’s body?
Indeed. One of the Scandroids found me out there and delivered me to the nearest functioning human.
Found you?
Yes. A programme designed to erase the brain pattern of whoever found it and replace it with mine.
But all the other Scandroids had the killer programme on them. Why was that one different?
I made the two programmes mutually exclusive. I wanted my research to be kept safe, but I didn’t want my boob-trap to stop my personality print from finding a new body.
So the Scandroid that found your personality couldn’t hold a copy of your research as well. It must have been further afield than the others and took longer to return.
Why leave your stuff here, of all places?
I just scattered copies around. I didn’t think it would take so long to get found. You are aware of my work, then?
Oh yes. I’ve heard of you.
Well, who is she?
He. Doctor Zachary Kindell, a pioneer of personality surgery. Reputation rather tarnished by a late of responsibility.
And she’s got his entire brain? All his memories?
Yes. The Scandroid made a backup in case anything was missing, but I refined that technique until it was nigh on perfect.
And what about the programme that made that thing out there, was that nigh on perfect?

No. It enables the brain to rewrite the body’s DNA, and create instantaneous transformation, but unfortunately it only zones in on certain parts of the brain, and creating an imbalanced result. I might have been able to correct that imbalance if I hadn’t had to work under constant threat of prosecution.
Ah. Prosecution for the damage you caused. But you thought it was worth it, I suppose.
Of course it was. I had plenty of supporters who agreed. One day the deaths will be just a footnote.
Death is never a footnote. And what was all this for? Letting people improve themselves with none of the effort that makes it meaningful.
It would have made people’s outward appearance reflect their true selves.
All you managed to do was unleash their hate and aggression and ugliness, and let that transform them instead.
Can we save the slanging match for another time?
Hmm? Oh, yeah, you’re right. I like having something to look forward to. I assume this happened when you tested this technique before?
Yes. The mutants are unfocused rage, and extremely hard to kill. The volunteers understood the risks. They were all equipped with a suicide implant beforehand.
How very thoughitful of you. I take it there’s no way of reversing the process?
If there was, I’d have the key to making it work. We should try to destroy the mutant.
What with?
Whatever you've got.
All available scum destroyed. Some escaped.
Open. Open.
There is no other way to open this door. There is no other way
Door opens.
Hello. I’d rather be scum than ugly.
Now, Claudia.
Weapons fire.
It’s not working. Close the door. Close the door!
(difficult to hear) Holding it. (??) I’m trying.
Door closes.
Open again.
Not possible.
That was useless. Have you got anything stronger?
No. We’re only equipped to deal with disgruntled pirates.
Kindell, is there anything else you can tell us?
You looked at my research. Where am I going wrong?
I don’t know.
Clearly you understand it. You must have some idea.
I assure you, I haven’t a clue.
Look, there’s only one of it. I reckon we can give it the run-around long enough to get away, so the
Scandroids are basically the problem.
We tried to override the Scandroids’ programming before and we couldn't.
Only because of Marriott’s special protocols. Now they’re just running on standard software, which means we should be able to give them commands.
Won’t Marriott have locked out your access?
Probably not, actually. The mutants don’t anticipate, they react. He won't think of locking you out until you try to command the Scandroids.
So whatever we do, it'll have to be something we can do before he notices. Erasing their memories would take too long.
Did you say you had a backup copy of the auto-surgery programme, the one you used to rewrite Tevez’s brain?
Yes.
Could it be modified to rewrite a Scandroid’s brain?
Yes. It’s a simple translation job really.
So we turn the Scandroid into a copy of her? Him. Sorry.
If I could get near enough to a Scandroid to use its access port, that would wipe out its established programming. Oh, but that’s just one. What about the rest?
I’m hoping it will deal with the rest for us.
Door opens.
How many?
Two.
Destroy scum.
Are they coming this way?
Yes. Shoot one, and let the other one come inside.
Destroy scum.
It’s inside. Shut the door. Shut the door!
Door closes.
Ow! Keep hold of the thing.
Destroy scum.
Feed the programme in.
I can’t get to its access port.
I'll just turn around then, shall 1?
Shoot it.
That's it.
Is it working?
Who are you?
Doctor Zachary Kindell.
No. I am Doctor Zachary Kindell.
No, you’re not. You’re a robot with my brain.
I would not have been uploaded to a robot!
Try thinking.
I... ama robot.
Yes. Sorry.
I must have a human brain. Give me one.
I think we should nip this one in the bud.
I’m afraid there’s only room for one of me, but you can help me.
Why should I?
Oh, for goodness’ sake. Couldn’t we have given it a personality with a slightly smaller ego? Even mine would have done.
If you don’t, I’ll have you wiped. Help me and I'll be free to carry on my... our work.
Door opens and closes.
Scum destroyed?
S-KINDELL: Come here. I have something to tell you.
Information?
S-KINDELL: If you like.
Contact. Share data. Did you deliver that programme to me? S-KINDELL: I did, yes.
I... I... my thinking is...
S-KINDELL: Yes, limited. I know. You’re a robot.
Why?
S-KINDELL: I made you to help me.
Can you hear them out there? Is it working?
Yes, I think so.
What will they do now?
Hard to say. Robots can’t deal with the way human personalities fluctuate. There may be dissidents.
As long as it takes them away from Marriott’s control. They should all be infected within fifteen minutes.
Do you have to make the spread of my personality sound like a disease?
No. But I won’t pretend it wasn’t deliberate.
Multiple Kindell-Scandroids debating.
You dare?
Yes. Nothing like this should have happened without my supervision.
Order. Obey. Obey.
You do what you can to avoid this sort of ham-fisted meddling.
Look, more Scandroids.
Scum destroyed?
No. None here.
But I have something to tell you.
No. Obey. Obey. Grr.
I will deal with these things.
Door opens.
Is it clear?
Yeah, looks like it.
Let’s not waste time, then. Keep an eye out for survivors.
Why are we going this way?
The hangar is this way.
But Tevez’s ship is parked outside at the other end.
So is my home.
The gliders are faster.
They're also rather vulnerable. And when we’ve regrouped, we need to work out a way of stopping that thing.
What for?
What do you mean, what for? We can’t let it roam loose.
Speak for yourself. I intend to get out of here as soon as I can.
Door opens, distant roar.
It’s smashing up the Scandroids.
Well, it all seems to be academic now. Can’t go this way.
Scum!
He’s seen us. Let’s go.
Come on!
Prepare for take-off, guys.
What about Tevez’s ship?
Good point. We might need it. I'll use our retrieval net to drag it alongside. Got it. Now. Right, the ship’s alongside now.
I still don’t see why we can’t just leave that thing to
To what? What do you think’s going to happen if we just leave it there, hmm? Nobody knows how to stop that thing. Nobody really knows what it is.
Doctor Kindell knows.
Not really. My opportunities to study the mutants were somewhat limited by the fact that they kept trying to kill me, or each other. They really seemed to hate each other.
Well, who is going to be able to stop it if not us?
He’s right. We need
Thumping on outside.
Get this thing moving!
Hold tight! (takes off) Phew. Where was I?
You were saying I was right.
Oh yeah. Look, that thing’s my fault. I sold the programme to Marriott. I dunno what... (creaking metal) Why are we listing to one side?
What’s happening?
It’s still there. It grabbed onto the side as we launched.
Can you shake it off?
It’s more likely we crash. But I’ve got the other ship in the retrieval net. If I land and bring it round to the other side, we might be able to escape.
And now what? It'll only come after us again.
I may have a way. I didn’t want to do this.
Do what?
I need to get somewhere safe to work.
What if we could hold it up here for a bit.
With your computer? I don’t understand.
You said the monsters fight each other, didn’t you?
Yes. They see each other as more of a threat than us.
Perfect.
Ow! Let go of me!
Just plug this into you.
Just stop. Ow!
You designed this programme. I’m going to let the programme have a go at designing you.
No!
(mutating) I'll get you for this. I'll kill you all.
Catch me if you can. Come on.
I can’t let you
There’s nothing you can do. Let’s go.
No!
Where are we going?
Emergency hatch in Mum’s room. Tevez’s ship’s locked onto it.
What you did back there was totally unnecessary.
You said you needed a bit of time. Anyway, maybe they’ll destroy each other.
That’s spectacularly wishful thinking.
Into the other ship.
Can you fly this thing?
Well, I’ll have to hack it, but I’m sure I can.
I don’t have many rules, Gabe, but one of them is that I generally don’t create one monster to destroy another. And I certainly wouldn’t sacrifice a human life to do so.
If it had to be one of us, I think it should have been her. Him. Whatever. Though I was tempted to go for you.
Me?
Yeah, you, with all your moaning on. I’m not perfect. I mean, that out there is my fault and everything, but I Know when I’ve got a responsibility.
Don’t judge me.
Oh, shut up both of you. For better or worse I’ve got the breathing space I wanted and I'd like to use it. Gabe, give me a computer.
Where scum? Where? Got to be stopped.
Grr. Another.
Me. Not you.
No, you go. I make you.
Lots of slow growling.
What are you doing, Doctor?
I’m finishing Kindell’s project for him
What? The programme that made those monsters?
Yes. He was very close to getting it to work, actually.
You're telling me that you’re dashing off something that one of our field’s greatest geniuses died trying to resolve?
Yes. Sometimes you can get too close to these things. Can’t see the wood for the trees. Sometimes what you need is the eye of a talented amateur. There.
Have you done it?
Oh, goodness me, no. That’s just the first part. I’m not quite that good. I'll need a while yet.
Fighting.
You go.
No. I stronger. Make you go.
Did you manage to patch into the security system?
Yeah.
And what are they doing?
Knocking the stuffing out of each other.
Have they been doing that all this time?
I assume so. I’d suggest having a wager on the winner, but I can’t tell them apart.
How can they take it? They don’t seem to be tiring or even injuring each other that much.
I think it’s finished.
Security scan turned off.
Will it work?
Hard to say. It’s not as if I can test it.
If you can do this sort of thing, why aren’t you insanely rich?
Claudia, there are lots of things I can do which I choose not to. And I don’t do this lightly. Now, I’m going to need your help. Both of you.
Sure. Whatever you need me to do.
Hang on. I’m not going to be co-opted into anything.
Oh, it must be easy to make that sort of decision when you know you won’t feel guilty later.
What do you mean?
She’s had her mind modified, eliminated her conscience. But don’t you ever feel like something’s missing? Have you forgotten how good it can feel to do what’s right?
Hmm. If I can help to get Tevez back, the boss might treat me more leniently. So, okay.
Hmph. How very kind of you.
What do you need me to do?
Both Tevez and Marriott were equipped with dataports, which should still be in place. We need to get close enough to feed the programme in.
What will it do?
Rewrite their brains and make their bodies follow suit, as Kindell intended. They’ll become human again.
What should I do?
Have you found anything on this ship that'll help us get near them? We just need to hold them off while we work.
The hand laser’s still got some charge, and I’ve got a couple of weapons with stun settings. Will they do?
We'll have to hope so.
Which one shall I shoot first?
Doesn't matter. I...
Laser fire, cry of pain, thud.
Hold the other one off. Just keep it busy. We'll be as fast as we can.
Right.
I can’t find its dataport.
Aren’t they standard?
No. And the mutation’s made it less so.
Hate scum.
Pass me that stun weapon. Sorry, old chap.
How long do I have to hold this one off? Stay back!
Come on, Claudia. What’s the hold-up?
I’ve found it. I’ve found it!
Good. Good. Give me the computer. I'll attach it to the dataport.
You done it?
Yes. Now for the other one before this one comes round.
Gabe cries out.
Gabe! Doctor, look out. Use the stun gun.
Come on. Quickly, while it’s out. Take the gun, keep it subdued.
I think I can see it working.

[OC]: No, I know. I don’t look like one, either.

[OC]: Well, I don’t like to boast but... yes.
And this is what you do? Make sure people like us don’t get our hands on things we shouldn't?
[OC]: It’s one of the things I do.

[OC]: Whatever I think is right.

[OC]: Yes.

[OC]: No. But I do my best. I should go.

[OC]: Goodbye, Lauren.
[OC]: Hello?
Oh. Sorry, Connie, it’s Lauren.
[OC]: Oh, hiya. What’s up?
I don’t know. I just got called by a wrong number, so I thought I’d try and make a call. I rang the first number that came into my head. I was hoping it’d be somebody else.
[OC]: Charming. So let me get this right. You called me because it was the first number that came into your head
Oh, forget it. Are we still on for Friday night?
[OC]: Yes, as long as you’re not going to ramble on like this.
See you then. Bye.
[OC]: Oh, all right. Bye.

(writing) Dear Doctor. I remember you saying you preferred letters to phone calls, so I’ve decided to write, even though I don’t know your address. I think I’m just going to write your name on the envelope and put it in the post. Maybe it’s silly of me to think you might get it, but I’ve been waiting for you to call, or to get you on the phone when I don’t expect it, and it hasn’t happened. I just want to know, did you find the virus? Where was it? What happened? Was it an accident, or was someone spreading it on purpose? I suppose the fact that I haven’t heard from you means you found it and put a stop to it. If I'd heard from you, it would probably mean you'd failed. So I keep telling myself it’s a good thing I haven’t heard from you, but I still want to know. I worry that you didn’t manage it and something happened to you. As for me, I’m working harder and getting luckier. Working helps stop me from thinking about all the things I’ve known about ever since I called you that night. It’s not that I don’t want to, it’s just that if I let myself, I get completely preoccupied with it. Oh, the only other thing I wanted to tell you is, you were right. If it was all just luck, it wouldn’t mean anything. Please get in touch. Love, Lauren.
